wikipedia_page.main: David O. Pam (February 1920 - 17 August 2014) was a British librarian and local historian known for his works on the history of Edmonton and Enfield and other areas of the former Edmonton Hundred.

The moat is protected under the Ancient Monuments & Archaeological Areas Act 1979. A survey of the area conducted between 1656 and 1658 attributes the site as the seat of habitation of Geoffrey de Mandeville during the reign of William the Conqueror.David Pam, The History of Enfield Chase, Enfield Preservation Society, 1984.  A 2019 report states that the "earliest documented reference to this site comes from the 14th century. There is also a documented fact that in May 1439 instructions were given to demolish the 'Manor of Camelot', suggesting there was a building on the site".https://friendsoftrentcountrypark.org.uk/wp-content/uploads/TRENT-COUNTRY-PARK-MAP-BROCHURE-EDITV2.pdf, Trent Park brochure Another source indicates that a lodge was located on this site, and demolished in 1429 and the materials sold to help pay for repairs to Hertford Castle.

A house had stood on the site since at least the 16th century. David Pam dates the construction of the house to 1553.Pam, David. (1994) A history of Enfield Volume three - 1914 to 1939: A Desirable neighbourhood. Enfield: Enfield Preservation Society. p. 198.  The court rolls of the manor record that William Copwood of Totteridge disposed of some part of Danegrove, or what it then was composed of, to David Woodroffe, citizen and haberdasher of London (died 1563), who as sheriff oversaw the execution of two protestant martyrs in 1555 and was criticised for the cruelty of his methods. Woodroffe's wife Elizabeth took a life interest in the property following her husband's death but surrendered Danegrove (9 acres) and Daneland (12 acres) to other members of the Woodroffe family.

The Edmonton Hundred Historical Society is a historical society devoted to the study of the area covered by the Edmonton Hundred (a hundred being an ancient division of a county).Edmonton Hundred Historical Society page on N21.net, archived from the original on July 31st 2016. The society is a registered charity No. 299073.EDMONTON HUNDRED HISTORICAL SOCIETY. Charity Commission. Retrieved 22 September 2015. David Pam, FRHS, was the president until his death in 2014.Edmonton Hundred Historical Society page on N21.net, archived from the original on July 31st 2016.
